page.title: 12WADDINGTON FARM, BLACKBURN
page.content: Waddington Farm, in the Livesey area of Blackburn, has a riding school for the able-bodied and the disabled. The school was established in 1960 and takes about 250 disabled pupils every week. The riding lessons for the disabled are about 10 to 15 minutes long and the ages of the children taught range from 2 to 20. During a lesson three people supervise each horse to ensure the child's safety, one person on either side of the horse and one at its head. Mencap, a charity for the mentally handicapped, pays for some of the riding school's needs, for example the bridles. The horses are usually bought from friends of the owner and riding hats are bought second-hand from the Police Force.
